list.item: Collective plural has been removed for the sake of compatibility with other Slavic languages. It is considered as derivation, thus collective plurals are separate entries in the dictionary.
Two vocative forms exist with same MSD, e.g. narode / narodu (narod) are both Ncmsvn.

list.item: We distinguish three types of verbs: main, auxiliary and modal. The word bi is considered as particle, rather than verb copula.
Verb forms gerund and adverbial participle are taken to be separate (noun and adverb) lemmas.

Two types of (adjectival) participles exist: active and passive. Active corresponds to Macedonian L-form and passive to verbal adjective, neuter gender, singular. For example, nosel is encoded as VForm=Participle, Voice=Active, nosen as VForm=participle, Voice=Passive.

The passive participle is used in verbal forms with the auxiliary ima / nema (eng. to have, to have not). The verbal adjective, in case it is used out of this construction, is considered as separate lemma.
In cases where a lemma (and its wordforms) can be both progressive and perfective, Aspects is given the value ?-?, in order to avoid excessive ambiguity in the lexicon.

list.item: Negative adjectives are product of derivation, thus they belong to other types.
Words like moj, tvoj (eng. my, your) are considered possessive pronouns.
Words like prv, vtor (eng. first, second) are considered ordinal numerals.
Adverbs like mnogu, malku, nekolku are also considered adjectives, in cases they are used before nouns.

The list was extracted form the Macedonian MULTEXT-East lexicon.

list.item: Verbal adverbs (gerunds) like odejkji are not considered as verbal forms, but as separate adverbial non inflective lemmas
The adjectival adverbs (dobro, ispituvački) have the same adjective forms. Ambiguity is expected.
The adverbs that come sometimes before nouns (mnogu, malku, nekolku) can have definiteness in their inflectional paradigm. That is why these adverbs are considered as adjectives as well.
